title: Coronalinks 4/10: Second Derivative
summary:
Key ideas:
- The second derivative of total coronavirus cases has shifted to linear or sublinear growth in most European countries, as well as in the United States and the rest of the world.
- The immune system of bats has a low-grade infection with a bunch of viruses, which occasionally spread to humans.
- There is a possibility of voting entirely by mail for the November election in the US due to the epidemic.
- Turkmenistan and Brazil have denied the existence and seriousness of the virus, leading to potential harm.
- Top economists unanimously support lockdown as a preventive measure.
- The US has ramped up testing impressively fast, and the government has converted the Javits Convention Center into a 2,000 patient hospital in ten days.
- The Netherlands, Sweden, and Brazil are volunteering to be the control group for national lockdowns
- An aircraft carrier captain was fired for whistleblowing about how the Navy handled COVID-19
- The New York Times’ cover design is noteworthy
- There is a document called the Playbook For Early Response To High Consequence Emerging Infectious Disease Threats And Biological Incidents that outlines how to handle pandemics
- UK clinical guideline body NICE recommends against using NSAIDs for COVID-19
- Infectious disease experts did not accurately predict the number of COVID-19 cases
- There are two different interpretations of “flatten the curve”
- There is confusion around Elon Musk’s donation of BiPAP machines and not traditional ventilators

Key learnings:
- The containment strategies for the coronavirus are working for now, with a shift from exponential growth to linear/sublinear growth.
- Widespread flagrant unpunished violation of the law (such as denying the existence and seriousness of the virus) makes it challenging for the rest of us to take lockdown seriously enough.
- Top economists unanimously support lockdown as a preventive measure.
- The US has ramped up testing impressively fast, and the government has converted the Javits Convention Center into a 2,000 patient hospital in ten days.
- Different countries are approaching COVID-19 in different ways, which will provide a variety of data to analyze
- Whistleblowers are facing consequences for speaking out about how their organizations are handling COVID-19
- The media has provided contradictory information regarding COVID-19 prevention measures
- Experts are not always accurate in their predictions
- Follow established documents and guidelines to properly address health crises

Key questions:
- What is the best way to prevent the spread of the virus in countries like Turkmenistan and Brazil where leaders have denied its existence and seriousness?
- What are the potential consequences of voting entirely by mail in the November election in the US?
- How can people take lockdown seriously enough when there are widespread violations of the law, such as not wearing masks or denying the existence of the virus?
- What are the implications of a potential second wave of the virus for countries like the US that are currently contained?
- What can be done to protect whistleblowers who speak out about COVID-19 mismanagement?
- How can media outlets provide more accurate information to the public?
- What can be learned from the discrepancies in infectious disease experts’ predictions?
- How can organizations ensure they are properly handling COVID-19 using established guidelines?
- What is the best way to interpret “flatten the curve” to prevent confusion?
